articleinfo.title: Scheduling APRC Tool

sect2.title: Abstract
sect2.para: The ALMA Programme Review Committee Tool (APRC Tool) allows to simulate the execution of observation projects for one or more observation seasons and analyse the results of the simulation, as well as the distribution of projects with respect to several parameters. The APRC Tool uses the same algorithm that the online scheduling system uses to select the next scheduling block to run, the Dynamic Scheduling Algorithm, or DSA.

sect2.title: Scope
sect2.para: This document only covers the description and user manual for the Planning Mode Simulator and Scheduling internal data model. The explanation is throughout in this sense, but the DSA is not covered by this document. Please refer to "ALMA Dynamic Scheduling Algorithm" by Jorge Avarias and Rafael Hiriart for more information on this matter. For more information and software download, please go the this webpage

sect1.title: APRC Tool and DSA Architecture
sect1.para: shows the general architecture of the APRC and the DSA. The APRC integrates several data sources, depending on its configuration. These are shown in the left side of the diagram. The data sources used by the APRC are configured in $APRC_WORK_DIR/context.xml.

The APRC (and the DSA) uses an HSQLDB work database to perform its operations. Most of the data retrieved from the data sources is loaded into this relational work database, where it is stored in tables according to the DSA Data Model. Most of the DSA functionality is implemented as operations over the work database. It is advisable to gain some familiarity with the DSA Data Model, as it is the main model involved in the current implementation of the DSA and future additions as well. A description of the Data Model is given in .

Both the input data sources and the work database are accessed through Data Access Objects (DAOs). These are classes that allows access to the data through uniform interfaces, hiding the specific details involved in getting the data and transforming it to a common representation. This allows to connect the APRC (and the DSA) to different but equivalent data sources. For example, weather information is retrieved from historical files during simulation, but it is acquired by actual instrumentation when the DSA runs in the online system.

We are now able to describe how the APRC works. The APRC:
Loads data from different sources into the Work Database. This tasks is done by several Loaders.
Instructs the Dynamic Scheduling Algorithm to run a simulation. The simulation can be done for the entire configured period (typically 6 months, an observation season) or step through just one SB selection. This last mode is used mainly for development and testing.
When the simulation finishes, the APRC generates several reports. As all the data is persistent in the work database, it is possible to generate reports afterwards as well. Some reports that don't require a simulation run (such as the distribution of SBs though frequency bands, for example) can be generated as soon as the data is loaded.

The different data sources integrated by the APRC are:
ATM Tables
Atmospheric model tables. These tables hold opacity and brightness temperature for a range of frequency and PWV. These tables are included as part of Scheduling subsystem (specifically in the DSA jar file), and are loaded into the simulator only in full load command. From the simulator point of view this data is considered static.
Weather Historical Tables/Weather Instrumentation
Historical data for several parameters (temperature, opacity, wind direction, wind speed), for one year, with a resolution of 15 minutes. The simulator includes default simulated default values similar to the ALMA's site average weather.
This historical files are only used by the DSA when running in the context of the APRC. When the DSA runs with the online system, this data is retrieved directly from the instrumentation.
Light Project Files/APDM
ObsProposal, ObsProject and SchedBlock data. These two sources are complementary. Light Project files are XML files with a simplified structure (i.e.., simpler than the APDM) that contains only the parameters needed by the DSA. This alternative source for project information was primary conceived as a development and testing aid. Light Projects are maintained in $APRC_WOR_DIR/projects. APDM entities, on the other hand, are retrieved from the ALMA Archive XML Store.
Executive Data
Definitions for the Executives (i.e.., USA, Europe, Japan), and their respective observation time percentages. Currently this information is maintained in XML files stored in the $APRC_WORK_DIR/executives directory. Currently the definition of the PIs and their executive memberships are also defined here.
User Repository
The definition of the PIs will be taken from the ALMA User Repository, an LDAP database that is used by the ALMA-OT for user authentication. Currently is not being used by the APRC.
Observatory Characteristic DB/TMCDB/CONTROL Subsystem
The array configurations, and a definition of the hardware state versus time is currently stored as an XML file in $APRC_WORK_DIR/observatory. Some of this information will come in the future from the Observatory Characteristic Database, which will also be used by OBSPREP. When the DSA runs in the context of the online system, this information is retrieved from the TMCDB and the CONTROL subsystem.
Ph1M
The Ph1M tool maintains its own database to handle project and proposal information such as their scores and ranks. The APRC tool can load the scores and ranks directly from the Ph1M database. It can also reload them on demand.

sect2.title: Simulation Work flow
sect2.para: The simulation is bound to the availability of the data in the Working DB. For this reason a very strict work flow is defined in the form of a state machine. This State machine is handled internally by the simulator and it is exposed to the user through the available actions at certain point of the simulation. shows the representation of the state machine defined for the simulation work flow.

The following is a brief summary of each state:
Start
This is the initial state of the simulator, when no data has been loaded yet into the working DB. Usually this state is reach only after deleting manually from disk the working DB.
Static Data Loaded
In this state only static data (e.g. Weather simulation data, PWV interpolation tables, etc) are loaded into the Working DB. At this point the simulator is not ready to use, hence loading projects, executives and simulation dates are required. This state can be reach doing a Clean after a simulation has been completed.
Dynamic Data Loaded
In this state static and dynamic data (e.g. Projects, Executive Observation cycle, etc) has been already loaded into the Working DB. In this state the simulator is ready to start. This state can be reach doing a Full Load or a Load after a Clean.
Simulation Completed
In this state the simulation has already saved the information required to generate all the reports. Since the simulation is already completed (and the Run Simulation command has been completed), the only action possible is to clean the dynamic data, and then start a new simulation using fresh loaded projects.

sect1.title: The APRC Tool
sect1.para: The APRC Tool works with two different directories: the APRC distribution directory, usually the aprc directory in the distribution tarball; and the APRC work directory, pointed by $APRC_WORK_DIR and set as default to aprc/work_dir.

All the functionalities of the APRC Tool are available through the WebUI. In the past a Command Line Interface (CLI) was provided, but due the lack of use and resources to maintain it has been deprecated. However it still available but unsupported.

The APRC distribution directory contains all the executables, libraries and scripts needed to run the APRC. It contains the following subdirectories and files:
work_dir/
Global configurations for the APRC tool. One of the important files here is the scheduling.properties which sets the Scheduling DSA policies to load.
doc/
Documentation.
lib/
Java and WebUI libraries.
logs/
Contains the log output generated during the execution of the simulation. Every time that the simulator is started it will create a new log file.
README
The README file with important information related to the current APRC Tool distribution.
pmsLauncher.jar
This special jar file contains an embedded version of jetty servlet engine and all their dependencies to start the WebUI as simple as possible.
test_array_configs.txt
This is an example of how the arrays configuration file has to be created.
testPolicy.xml
An example of a Scheduling DSA policy file. It contains a basic DSA policy definition ready to be used.
start_simulator
This script will setup the $APRC_WORK_DIR environment variable and the DSA internal configuration to use the provided configuration files. Then it will start the embedded jetty servlet engine and it will try open your browser to the main page of the simulator running locally in your machine (This will work on the official supported platform RHEL 5). If it is not possible to open the browser it will show a message indicating the where to point your browser.

The APRC work directory, on the other hand, contains the datasets, the HSQLDB Work database, and other specific configurations. Its contents are:
aprc-config.xml
Several configuration parameters, such as the name of the directories below, the Spring context file to use, and other parameters such as the Executive grades and the array center location.
scheduling.properties
This file is used to configure the working DB backend to be used within the APRC Tool. Also is used to configure which DSA Scheduling Policy file will be loaded when the APRC Tool starts.
archiveConfig.properties
If the ALMA Archive DAO will be used to import projects, then this file must be configured properly to get the connection to the ALMA Archive. This works only inside ALMA JAO network.
executives/
As discussed above, this directory holds Executive data files.
observatory/
As discussed above, this directory holds Observatory data files.
projects/
As discussed above, this directory holds Light Project data files.
weather
As discussed above, this directory holds weather data files.
output/
As discussed above, this directory is used to output reports.
reports/
This directory holds the reports created by the tool.
hsqldb/
This directory is used by the HSQLDB Work database. Deleting this directory will reset the APRC Tool simulator to the start state. This directory must be removed only once the Simulator has been shut down.

sect2.title: Preparing a DSA Policies file
sect2.para: The DSA Policies file is an XML Document based on an XML Schema. The documentation available for this XML Schema is available here. The XML Schema itself is available here. An example of this file is provided with the APRC distribution, check for more details.

The DSA Policy file to load at APRC Tool startup is defined in the scheduling.properties file. The property dsa.policy.file must be modified or added to point to your DSA policy file. It is recommended to put the absolute path of this file, however relatives paths to the root of the APRC tool (the aprc directory) are supported. The APRC Tool package distributed in a tarball shall come with a DSA policy file pre-configured already.

sect1.title: The APRC Tool Web User Interface
sect1.para: The APRC Graphical User Interface (or GUI), is a web application that allows access to the simulator functionality. It has the same capabilities as the CLI, and the ability to present multiple reports on screen. It uses the same technologies as the Ph1M tool, so it can be easily integrated with this application.

sect2.title: Architecture
sect2.para:
The architecture of the GUI follow a strict Model-Controller-View pattern. The framework used to achieve this pattern is ZK, which is a rich internet application (RIA) framework, that allows quick prototyping, but also has several enterprise qualities, such as automatic data mapping from user interface to controller, Spring framework and Hibernate integration, which are the same layers of frameworks that the scheduling subsystem has selected to develop the APRC simulator and the DSA.
View
To construct the views, ZK provides ZUL, a language based on XML and XUL, which are both widely used for user interface definitions. It allows the developers to see exactly how the interfaces will look (using a provided eclipse plug-in, called "ZK Studio"). ZUL is very powerful, even allowing to embed Java code in the interface definition. This functionality will not be used, as to better separate the definition of the view, from the controller.
Controller
In the MVC pattern, controller is that piece of software that handles the logic of the interface. The intention of this separation (between view definitions, and logic) is such that views can be easily changed, without much effort, enhancing maintainability of the software, and allowing make quick changes easy. Java classes that uses ZK's auto-mapping features allows transparent access to view definitions. Even changes to it can be made from Java code.
Controllers are automatically binded from the View definition. ZK allows intelligent and automatic binding between attributes defined at view layer, with the controller actions. This helps to reduce coding time, and provides a cleaner code.
Model
The model section of the MVC pattern, takes care of data handling. Not only it's storage, but also it's processing. In this case, it will be the APRC tool libraries, and the work database. This is intended to reuse all the code between the CLI and the GUI, and to allows the same tools, to have the same behaviour. All the specification of this layer, corresponds to the same in

sect2.para: Views are the user interfaces. This section contains a few examples of user views that are available in the GUI prototype. The prototype if not yet functional, but his has data access capabilities, and navigation is possible. The views are not yet settled, as this are only for technology-tests and to see if the selected stack of frameworks integrates correctly.

The interface has a window, that uses the whole web page. It has menu bar, where all functionality can be found, according to the context of the selected window. A predetermined set of tasks are set when there is no other active window.

The menu entry "Simulation", allows to create new simulations, load previous one, and save them. The menu "View" is set there to organize the windows, when there are too many in the web page. "Help" entry has links to this manual, download page, and information of the software itself.

When a simulation is created, different data sources needs to be selected. Data sources are provided by the APRC tool back-end, and the window depicted in presents to the user the different options available.

At this moment, the simulator allows to choose the data sources between the ALMA Archive DAO, which uses the ALMA Archive when is possible (it requires to be in the ALMA JAO network and configure properly the archiveConfig.properties file) and the XML Projects DAO, which loads the projects contained in the $APRC_WORK_DIR/projects directory.
The same window also has two side panels. The upper one gives the status of the simulation, meanwhile the lower one, presents to the users the most common tasks to execute.

sect1.title: The DSA Data Model
sect1.para: The DSA works internally with a data model conformed by a collection of Java classes that are made persistent (i.e.., its fields are stored persistently so the state of the class can be recovered) in the Work Database's relational tables. The structure of the tables is very similar to the Java data model, although classes in Java use inheritance and other object oriented constructs that don't exists in the relational model.

The Data Model is divided in the following packages:
executive
obsproject
observatory
weather
output
The source code can be found in the SCHEDULING/Common module.

A class diagram for the executive package is shown in . The main classes are ObservingSeason and Executive. There are two many-to-many relationships between these two classes, which are represented by ExecutivePercentage and ExecutiveTimeSpent. The first represents how much time a given Executive has for a given ObservingSeason. This class also holds the Executive remaining observation time. As a simulation is executed, ExecutiveTimeSpent records are created, recording the SBs that are executed and how much time should be charged to their corresponding Executive.

The relationship between a SB and an Executive is made though the PI. A PI can be related to more than one Executive. This relationship is represented in the PIMembership table. For convenience, this relationship is also maintained directly, as a link between SchedBlock and Executive.

The obsproject package class diagram is shown in . This package follows closely the APDM structure, although only the fields that are relevant for the DSA are used. Also, some additional classes and fields that are not present in the APDM have been added.

In some cases, the DSA needs to update some of the objects with a certain periodicity. These are marked as "DatabaseUpdateable". For example, the WeatherDependenVariables class, that contains the Tsys and projected Tsys, is updated for the relevant SchedBlocks at the beginning of each DSA iteration. FieldSourceObservability, in the other hand, which contains the LST rising and setting time for a source, only needs to be updated once, at the beginning of a simulation run.

The observatory package can be seen in . This section aims to represent the state of the telescope hardware throughout the time interval covered by the simulation, including the program of array configurations.

The telescope hardware devices are modeled as being either an Assembly, or a TelescopeEquipment, which can contain other TelescopeEquipment, and/or Assemblies. This hierarchical structure follows the design of the TMCDB.

Changes in the hardware state are stored as operations over the assemblies or groups of assemblies. The actual state of the hardware at a given point in time is dealt with following the same design represented by "DatabaseUpdateable". Records are updated periodically, following the defined operations.

An Antenna and a Pad are linked by AntennaInstallation, a link that is time-dependent. Several AntennaInstallations conform an ArrayConfiguration. The DSA will start a different scheduler for each ArrayConfiguration.

The weather section is very simple, and is shown in . The atmospheric model table is maintained as AtmParameters records, and historical weather data is represented as different types of WeatherHistRecords.

Lastly, displays the output package. This package includes classes that represent and summarize the results of a simulation. Basically, the simulation Results integrate both the Arrays that were created during the simulation time, and the ObservationProjects that contained SBs that were executed in the Arrays. SB executions are recorded as SchedBlockResult instances.
